titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: Letter from Joseph Sturge, Birmingham . . .

Letter from J. D. Reymert Boston 29. June of the house of William and Charles Young Ironmongers and wire Merchants Edinburgh and Glasgow, recommends J. P. Robinson . . . agent at Boston— With cards, catalogue and engravings of iron and wire articles.

H.R.U.S— Tariff Bill in Committee of the whole on the State of the Union Cobb Chairman James Thompson of Pennsylvania closed his tariff speech and reply to Yancey’s excommunication— Robert M. T. Hunter followed against the Tariff— Then Toombs of Georgia for it. Then Billy Wick of Indiana, bitter upon Brinkerhoff the Ohio braggart. Charles H Carroll a Marylander transplanted to 29 New-York a Tariff whig contrasted by David Wilmot 12 Pennsylvania the solitary but serious anti tariff man from that State— Felix G M’Connell of Alabama decent? against the tariff I left him speaking and at 4 PM went and dined with Winthrop and the party at Mrs Whitwells—returned after 6. and found Barringer of North Carolina, speaking against the Bill.— Albert Smith 33 New-York for the tariff and Frederick P— Stanton 10 Tennessee against it had spoken while I was absent.— Barringer was followed by Orlando B Ficklin 3. Illinois, anti-tariff—then Joshua F. Bell 4. Kentucky. Tariff About 9 P.M Thomas Perry 2. Maryland took the floor for the Tariff— I was wearied out, left the house, missed a step in descending from the outer porch, fell prostrate and struck my left knee pan on the stone— Slight bruise Walked out of the yard. Met Thomas Dumphy with the Carriage and rode home.— After I left the house—Root of Ohio, Miller of New-York Daniel of North-Carolina—Hough of New-York, Hampton of New-Jersey, Houston of Delaware and Lewis of New-York kept the house in Session till Midnight when they adjourned to . . . the morning

I wrote a note of acknowledgment and thanks to Mrs Macomb for her kind note with the Georgetown Advocate of 18 June headed with my name and written by her brother Balch— H.R.U.S. Speaker took the chair at 9. Call of the house to make a quorum— James M’Dowell moved to suspend the rules for a resolution, that after closing the debate at 2 P.M discussion upon the proper amendments should be allowed, each member not to exceed 15 minutes, referred— I found Meredith P. Gentry 7 Tennessee speaking for the Tariff of 1842— The chairman next gave the floor to Ashmun— Rathbun 25 New-York claimed it against Cobb’s peremptory decision, and Ashmun yielded— He thought Rathbun would be valiant against the Bill, and he was—but voted for it. Brinkerhoff’s doubler Joseph R. Ingersoll 2 Pennsylvania, Norris of New Hampshire, Jefferson Davis of Mississippi brought the debate to a close at 2. P.M.— The voting on amendments was commenced and continued till near 7—when the Committee rose without concluding and the house adjourned to 10 tomorrow morning— The Senate this day passed by a vote of 32 to 13. the bill which on the 8th of May last the House had passed retroceding the County of Alexandria to the State of Virginia— John Davis of Massachusetts voted for it— Daniel Webster was absent— The Constitution is waste paper— The District of Columbia was a delusion. The link of continuity to the chain of the Union is dissolved and the next step will be the removal of the seat of Government to a Slave State

I receive almost every day Letters from entire Strangers, asking for documents, or autographs or money.— I have a Letter from Curtis and Rall, Cincinnati 13. June 1846 making enquiries concerning certain pension claims, for which I applied to the Office of the Clerk of the House without success. C. Hughes urged me to go with him to morrow to Baltimore dined with the Society of Cincinnati and go with him to Church on Sunday but I declined— H.R met at 10— The whole day was consumed in voting upon amendments first in Committee of the whole by tellers and after the bill was reported with amendments to the house by yeas and nays— The struggle to strike out 20 per Cent on tea and Coffee was successful—that to make salt free finally failed fishing bounties abolished and restored— Casting vote of the Speaker against freedom of Salt— Mistake of counting votes— Reconsideration 20 per cent on salt— All amendments proposing specific for ad valorem duties rejected—100 per cent for spiritous liquors—final vote on the bill 114 to 95— All the democracy whipped in— Tibbatts moved the reconsideration to clinch the bill Democratic Io Triumphe— 6. O Clock P.M. adjourned over to Monday— Rains incessant. Invitation from the Mayor and City Council of Boston to the Anniversary celebration there to-morrow— I cannot attend— Answer I suppose unnecessary.

Independence day— 70 years are gone— The average limitation of the life of man. Public celebrations as recommended and foretold by my father were held throughout the land, but not with so much hilarity and bustle as usual in this city— A noon walk for exercise of an hour was my only excursion from the house. The day was showery and sultry Mr and Mrs J. J. Crittenden, Mr and Mrs Joshua F. Bell of Kentucky Mr and MrsKaufman of Texas, Mr. William A— Moseley of Buffalo New-York, and Dr John M Thomas were our visitors.— Nor this nor any other day can ever pass over my head without cordial gratitude to the giver of all good for all the numberless blessings of his bounty thoughout my life, with supplication for the continuance of his mercies, and deep humility at my own errors and sins— A solemn admonition of the frailty and precarious tenure of human life occurred this day in the sudden death of Mrs. Julia Dickinson Tayloe, wife of Benjamin Ogle Tayloe of this city—in a fit while taking a shower bath— She was the only daughter of the late John Dickinson of Troy New-York, and was a woman of fine understanding, a cultivated mind, engaging manners, lovely temper, and active, bountiful charity— I received the New-York Sun Newspaper of yesterday containing honorary verses upon my name, with the signature of Felix Farley—and a Letter from the Author C. W. Holden

Revd. Daniel Baker of Holly-Springs Mississippi preached this morning in the Hall of the house of Representatives from Matthew 28.6— Come see the place where the Lord lay— Mr Baker discourses much in the same as he did in former days, but with more self confidence and a more authoritative tone. The auditory thin but the President and Mrs Polk were there— Dr Thomas came at noon, and mentioned that an informal funeral service would be performed at 4 O’Clock this afternoon at the house of Mr Benjamin Ogle Tayloe, over the remains of his deceased wife, and that they would be immediately afterwards removed to the railway Cars, and transported to the residence of her mother Mrs Dickinson, at Troy, in the State of New-York— I attended accordingly, with my wife, Mrs John Adams and Louisa, at the house— A small company of relatives and friends of the two families were there, and Mr Pyne after a short and feeling address to the company assembled read several of the appropriate prayers from the episcopal book of common prayer, and the coffin was then removed to the hearse and carried to the Railway depot of the Cars for Baltimore— Mr Tayloe himself goes with the remains: also Mr Hubbard, member of H.R. from Connecticut a kinsman of Mrs Tayloe. There was no procession of Carriages.— We returned and spent the Evening at home—

I received a Letter from H. D. Clark, Elyria Lorain County Ohio 1. July 1846 annexed to which is a petition from William Ricke of Carlisle Township Lorain County Ohio, formerly of Sudbury Vermont, son as he states of John Ricke, a warrior of the Revolution and of the preceding French wars, who died 5. Augt 1793 and left him continental paper money bills 196 1/3 dollars, of which with interest he asks payment.— H.R.U.S. Edward W. M’Gaughey 7. Indiana moved an amendment of the Journal, stating the facts of the Speaker’s escamotage on the votes for making salt duty free and then imposing upon it a duty of 20 per cent—but he had expunged all that part of the proceedings as null and void— He ruled M’Gaughey’s motion out of order— M’Gaughey appealed. Cobb moved to lay the appeal on the table which was carried, 90 to 52— Jacob Brinkerhoff asked to make a personal explanation, for which the rules were suspended— Explanations from Wick and Rathbun. Wick’s Letter 12. June— Sharpshooting and pummeling of New-York Loco Focos. All smoke— Washington Hunt’s epigram— Augustus Dodge presents a new Constitution of Iowa—adopted May 1846: to lay on the table and be printed— Reports, majority and minority of the select Committee on the public painting of Congress. Henley—Garrett Davis and Benton of New York. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Orlando B Ficklin of Illinois chairman— Bill to reduce and graduate the price of public Lands— Skirmishing debate— Brodhead and Hoge— Motions for the close of the Session. Message—M’Cleod correspondence, War Appropriations Treasury Notes— Adjourned—

Midsummer weather set in— Letter from Charles A. Davis, 3. July 1846. Modifying his new low tariff doctrine, of counteracting foreign cheapness of labour, by internal facilities of transportation. From George M Justice, Philadelphia, urging the importation of Telescopes duty free— From M. L. Grove—Fredericsburg Lebanon County Pennsylvania 3. July 1846 an Ironmonger enquiring my opinion whether the Tariff of 1842 will be modified.— A Sermon of War, by Theodore Parker, Minister of the 28th. Congregational church in Boston 7. June 1846— The Protestant Quarterly Review, and the American Review with a portrait of Daniel Webster—both for July 1846— At the House Ashmun moved to amend the journal by inserting in it the motion of M’Gaughey made yesterday— The Speaker decided Ashmun’s motion not in order— Joseph P. Hoge 6 Illinois had yesterday moved a joint Resolution to adjourn 27. July— This morning he modified it to 3. August.— Previous Question— Motion to lay on the table rejected—59 to 105— Rules had been suspended 98 to 48— Linn Boyd moved the gag on the Land graduation bill at 2. P.M— this day— His motion laid on the table— New debate on the adjournment— Andrew Stewart moved a reconsideration and finally withdrew the motion— Hoge himself renews it. Carried—question postponed to 21. July— Land graduation bill debated in Committee till there was no quorum; Call of the House, Anarchy of 2 hours— M’Kay’s Resolution adopted that the absentees shall account for their absence to-morrow morning. Adjourned at 1/2 past 6. without obtaining a Quorum— Evening visits from Healey, Major Graham and Thom.

FahrenheitLetter from my Son to his mother received— [symbols] Received also the July number of Redwood Fisher’s National Magazine— A concise view of Oregon Territory &c by Elijah White and Wiley and Putnam’s Literary Newsletter, and monthly Register of New Books Foreign and American published on the first of every Month at 165. Broadway—New York July 1846. Vol 5. N. 56— At the House two hours were again consumed in reversing the proceedings of less than a quorum yesterday to compel the attendance of the absentees— They were now the majority of a bare quorum and nullified the reversal by the majority yesterday of the Speakers decision that the motion of M’Kay requiring the absentees to account for their absence this morning, was not in order Tibbatts moved to expunge from the Journal all the proceedings of the no Quorum yesterday— This failed, but the reversal of Speakers decision against M’Kay’s motion was reversed, and the proceedings on the call annulled— M’Kay moved to suspend the rules, for two new rules, to enter the names of absentees on the journal, and publish them in the newspapers—but the house refused to suspend 71 to 86. Owen asked leave to introduce a bill to free from postage all correspondence with the army of occupation—refused, Harallson from the Military Committee asked leave to report a bill granting land to the soldiers and volunteers of the army of occupation—refused. Union Committee—Ficklin—Collamer, Henley Vinton, Gordon— Committee rose 1/2 past 3. Adjourned. Evening walk. Music on the grounds of the Presidents House— Met Waddy Thompson.

I deposited at the Bank of the Metropolis the draft for 112.50. received yesterday at the Bank of Washington, the quarterly dividend of interest on City Corporation 6 per Cent stock 7500 dollars. Nathaniel Chick 86. years old and a pension claimant of the Revolutionary and last English Wars came with a man named Donovan for my assistance— I took his papers to the Pension Office, and this Evening received from the Commissioner J— L— Edwards a report rejecting his claim as spurious— H.R.US. Alvan Cullom 4 Tennessee moved to consider a motion made by him to print an extra number of the Report from the Committee of Foreign Affairs the volunteer War Manifesto against Mexico, lost— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Land graduation bill— Opposed by Samuel Gordon 10 New-York, and most ably by Samuel F. Vinton 12 Ohio— Robert C. Schenck 3— Ohio, and dragooned on by W. W. Payne of Alabama— When Schenck finished the Committee rose, and received a Bill from the Senate for the same purpose, to give away the public lands under the name of graduation and reduction of price— The bill was immediately referred to the Committee, and there at once substituted for the house bill— Darragh 21. Pennsylvania opposed and Jacob Thompson of Mississippi supported it— Vinton took the floor— John A. M’Clernand 2— Illinois moved to close the debate at Noon to-morrow, adjourned The heat was so intense that I was compelled to intermit my evening walk, and to languish for my Potowmac baths which I must renounce for age—

I received a Discourse on the life and character of Sir Walter Ralegh delivered before the Maryland Historical Society 19— May 1846 the 3d. annual Address to that Association—by J. Morrison Harris— And a Letter from Thomas S. Donoho, of enquiries about the last line of the Sonnet to the Sun, eclipsed and beclouded on the 25th. of April 1846— Misprinted in a New-York Newspaper— H.R.U.S. M’Clernand’s motion to close debate on the Land graduation bill, modified to 2 P.M this day was adopted—and they went immediately into Committee— Vinton spoke the voice of the charmer to the adder.— Brockenbrough of Florida Reuben Chapman of Alabama, Dodge the Delegate from Iowa, Stephen Adams of Mississippi Representative of the Anglo-saxon Land robbers answered Vinton, and abused him for his honesty— James M’Dowell of Western had but five minutes to offer a substitute bill of his own. At 2— the voting commenced— Houston of Alabama, Andrew Johnson of Tennessee and Stewart of Pennsylvania, offered amendments and Darragh of Pittsburgh— Stewart to give 500000 acres to each of the old States—the rest to poor settlers.— All were rejected Samuel Gordon moved to lay the bill on the table—lost. Yeas and nays on the question of engrossment for a third reading—84 to 98. Daniel of North Carolina immediately moved a reconsideration— M’Clernand asked him what was his object— He said to amend the bill. yeas and nays 89 and 89. The Speaker gave the casting vote—ay— Reconsidered. Rockwell of Connecticut moved to adjourn 81 to 80— Carried. what became of 17 votes— Intense heat, no evening walk. Visit from James D Westcott of Tallahassee— Florida—
I enter upon my eightieth year. [symbols]

On going to the house this morning I ordered the Coachman Thomas Dumphy to come with the Carriage for me at 1/2 past 3. expecting that the house would adjourn about that time— But they adjourned before 2— Fahrenheit behind the Speaker’s chair 92— I went into the library and met there Mr John Connell— I inspected sundry pictorial cartoons of Wilkes’s exploring expedition, and also of a buffalo-hunt—disgusting, bulky animals suffering death by torture. At 1/2 past 3 I left the capitol, . . . . under shade of trees, till I met Dumphy with the carriage and came home— At the House Rathbun moved a call of the house 177 answered— Further call suspended 146 to 17— Motion to lay the bill on the table rejected 92 to 87. Henley moved to postpone the reconsideration till next Tuesday—lost 91 to 96. Charles S. Benton 17— New-York asked to be excused from voting, as he had paired off with James B. Hunt 3. Michigan— The house refused to excuse him and he voted— The motion to lay the bill on the table was again rejected, 89 to 91— Cobb withdrew his motion for the previous question— The house took up the private calendar—made some sluggish progress and adjourned before 2 O’Clock— Fahrenheit at 93— In the evening I had an intense longing for a warm bath— Dumphy took me to the baths in the rear of Brown’s hotel. They had no hot water, but said they would have some if I would wait, a half an hour—which I declined and rode home—but it was a sore disappointment. My birthday closes in debility but in unceasing blessings [symbols]

I rose with resignation to the will of God a living ruin, with the power of vital agency extinct—a plant withered at the root— A tree dying downward from the top— There was no preaching at the Hall of the Representatives, the Chaplain of the Senate Mr Tustin being sick—of Mr Milburn the Chaplain of the house, no Account. I attended Church this morning at St. John’s with my granddaughter Mary Louisa— My wife and Mary were not well enough to attend Church. Mr Pyne read the service for the 5th. Sunday after Trinity and preached from Psalm 38.18.—last clause of the verse— [“]I will be sorry for my sin”— At 5 in the afternoon I attended again at St. John’s church alone— Mr Pyne read the evening service of the day, and preached from 1. Corinthians 9–26. last clause of the verse [“]so fight I not as one that beateth the air”— Mr Pyne’s discourses are ingenious, argumentative, and well seasoned with the benevolence, if not with the morality of the Christian faith— His Christian must be sorry according to the rubric of the Church, and must expect his pardon through her Intercession— He fights not as one that beateth the air, and his Church is the church militant conquering and to conquer. In hoc signo vinces— He never for an instant loses sight of his church— I close the day as it had begun—with resignation—still longing for a bath and unable to collect my spirits for reading anything beyond the 3— chapters of the book of Job—25–27. with which I began the day— I made an attempt upon the philosophy of the plan of Salvation, but gave it up— Tried a few pages of Sartor resartus, and loathed it— Evening melted away without leaving a trace of existence behind.

I rose this morning with the dawn, and drawn by an irresistible impulse walked over the lower Tiber bridge, to my old bathing spot on the margin of the Potowmac—and there under the shelter of the high bluff yet remaining I bathed and swam from 5 to 10 minutes, and came out, dressed myself and walked home—a tour of an hour and a half— The exercise, the washing, the sensation of personal cleanliness, were as of old time, but the nervous agitation throughout the day was not sensibly relieved, and the weariness of the evening threatened a restless Night— Francis Richmond was here with T. L. M’Kenney’s Memoirs about Indians 2 volumes in one, of which I took a copy and father Green with papers of W. Roberts which he wished me to deliver to Preston King chairman of the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions H.R.U.S. Hugh White, moves a Committee of five to examine the accounts of the 5th. auditors—refused Dromgoole moves a message to remind the Senate of 4 bills sent them from the house— Vote to suspend the rules 39 to 72. Sundry bills from the Senate were passed or referred— Harralson reported a bill for granting lands to the soldiers—numerous other reports of Committees. Sawyer moved to suspend the rules for a call for the correspondence on the Oregon Treaty—refused—no yeas and nays. Land graduation bill. Call of the House—173 answer. Cobb’s amendment M’Kay’s amendment were rejected 87 and 95—and 88–93— Motion to lay the bill on the table 90 to 89. lost by the Speaker’s vote making a tie— Moved and lost again 91 to 92—and again 86. to 92. Rathbun moved to adjourn. Carried 89 to 85

IV— Second bath and swim in the Potowmack the weather still continuing at intense summer heat— My repose of the last Night was not impaired, but rather improved by the bath of yesterday. H.R.U.S. The race of reconsiderations was renewed at the first meeting of the house— The amendment moved by Cobb, and the amendment of that moved by M’Kay, after being both rejected had both been reconsidered— The previous question had been ordered, and M’Kay had moved to reconsider that— He now withdrew that motion and moved a call of the house which the Speaker pronounced not in order— Truman Smith moved to adjourn, and asked for the yeas and equivalent to a call of the house. 6 to 163. Schenk moved to reconsider the motion just rejected. The Speaker decided that a motion to adjourn could not be reconsidered— Schenk appealed, and stood alone in his glory— M’Kay’s substitute for Cobb’s amendment was then adopted 96 to 86— And M’Kay’s Bill substituted for that of the Senate was passed 92 to 90. Ewing of Pennsylvania remarked that C. J. Ingersoll did not vote— A motion to reconsider was laid on the table. Sundry bills received from the Senate one for the relief of Elizabeth Hamilton. Hoge moves to lay it on the table 69 to 81— Referred— Bill for the improvement of Ohio, Missouri, Mississippi and Arkansas inland Seas— Rejected 120 to 48. Treasury Note and loan bill. Garrett Davis discusses the Mexican War and offers an amendment to the Bill; Tilden, Giddings, Thurman of Ohio and Douglas of Illinois racketed the lie that the War began by an act of Mexico Tibbatts took the floor and the Committee Samuel Gordon chairman rose— M’Kay moved a Resolution to close the debate at Noon tomorrow— Adjourned without taking the question.

Third bath and swim in the Potowmack, at 5 O’Clock this morning: still with a clear sky and a bright rising Sun; but with a fall of ten degrees Fahrenheit from 84 to 74, and a brisk breeze ruffling the surface of the river so that I shivered while dressing at my old rock when I came out, but warmed in walking home, and suffer no after-inconvenience. Nathaniel Chick was again here this morning, 86. feeble—tottering at the gate of death— I took his papers to the Commissioner of Pensions and intreated him to re-examine them and reconsider his decision. He returned them this Evening with a Letter saying that he has no confidence in them and sees no evidence that Chick is entitled to a pension for service either in the war of the Revolution, or in the last War with England— H.R.U.S. M’Kays motion to close the debate on the Treasury Note and loan bill at Noon this day was carried— Garrett Davis, Stanton of Tennessee, Graham of North Carolina moved amendments which were rejected as was an additional section moved by Andrew Stewart. Joseph R. Ingersoll, moved an appropriation of 50000 dollars to pay certain old Treasury notes, once paid but stolen and reissued at New-Orleans—carried and the bill passed 118 to 47. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Morris Chairman— Volunteer appropriation bill 16,34347000— Garrett Davis, Thurman, Rathbun, Vinton, J. J. M’Dowell Henley and Houston of Alabama, debated the Bill and the Mexican War. Solomon Foot took the floor— Committee rose and house adjourned. Evening walk. Music in the Grounds of the President’s House. Mr John A— Rockwell came home with me, and took tea with us—

Fourth bath and swim in the Potowmack. Water and atmosphere cold, but smooth, with a clear sky— Still doubtful of the physical effect of this exercise and ablution— The tide still rising, but not yet high at 5 in the morning.— Mrs Burnet of Cincinnati and her son were here Nathaniel Chick came again— I could only tell him of the inflexibility of the Commissioner of Pensions Edwards; but as a last resource offered to go with him to the office— He said he felt so feeble that he preferred waiting till to morrow, to which I agreed— H.R.U.S. The day began by an explanation of Tibbatts against Stanton and Wick. M’Kay from the Committee of Ways and Means reported a supplemental appropriation bill for the pay of members of Congress and for the Indian Department Joseph R Ingersoll moved a joint Resolution authorising and requesting P.U.S. to cause medals to be struck from the trophies of the battles of Palo Alto and Resaca de la Palma to be distributed to every individual engaged in them—carried nem con— M’Kay moved a Resolution to close debate on the additional army appropriation bill at 2 P.M. Carried though Ashmun moved to lay it on the table— Cranston presented Resolutions of thanks of the Legislature of Rhode-Island to General Taylor for the victories of 8 and 9 May.— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Norris chairman on the additional army appropriation bill— 11,812015.09. to support 25000 volunteers for the year, and additional Officers to the army. Debated by Foote, Caleb B— Smith, Hilliard, Cobb &c reported to the house without amendment and passed 160 to 4 of whom I was one— Joint Resolution from the Senate to adjourn the Session 10. August—passed— Bill of more supplies for members of Congress and Indians resumed Wentworth Chairman— tumultuary and burlesque debate till about 4 when the Comee rose. Adjourned—

Fifth bath and swim in the Potowmack—and this day Thomas Dumphy went with me. Weather cool and cloudy. Water smooth and cold— Time of tide at 5 A.M. beginning to serve— Returned along the strand and the border of the Tiber— Nathaniel Chick came again, but still wished to postpone going with me to the pension office— He said he had written to the Governor of Pennsylvania for a certificate of character and wished to wait for his answer— I see he is unwilling to be confronted with Mr Edwards— I took him with me to his lodgings at Donovan’s next to the Railway depot. Kavasales here— Still in suspense— Mr Giddings went yesterday on a tour to Boston and Portland. H.R.U.S— The whole day was devoted to the private calendars— Sundry reports from Committees were received and variously disposed of— The house then took up the bills heretofore reported from the Committee of the whole, and what with motions to lay bills on the table, adopted and rejected seemingly as if by lot with motions to reconsider carried and postponed—with calls of the house to make a quorum adopted and superseded—with motions to adjourn reported and rejected 49 private bills were passed and sent to the Senate for concurrence— The vote to lay the Bill for the relief of William Poole on the table was reconsidered but when the question on the passage of the bill came there was no quorum voting and the house adjourned, about 3. I commenced my walk homeward and met judge Burnet with a young man named I think Derring an artist (Painter) who he said was going to Europe for improvement in his progression and for whom he requested from me Letters of introduction to any of my friends— I met the Carriage with Thomas Dumphy and rode part of the way in the Pennsylvania avenue, but he had to stop some time at a shop wherefore I got out and walked home— I began to read the Psalms 5 every day

IV.15— There was rain in the Night and this Morning was cloudy and cold— I concluded therefore reluctantly to intermit for some days my river baths. I have received an invitation to attend at the Commencement of Georgetown College on Tuesday the 28th. instant at half past nine O’Clock A.M. At the house sundry bills were received from the Senate and referred to Committees. The consideration of private bills occupied the remainder of time Till the adjournment at the adjournment at 3. first in Committee of the whole; Thomas Butler King Chairman, and then in the house— Among the Bills taken up was that for the relief of the heirs of Robert Fulton—an appropriation of 76300 dollars to be paid them in full of his demands Reported by Robert C. Schenk from the Committee on Naval affairs— When the bill came up, Schenk the reporter was not in the house, and several attempts were made, to pass over the bill to defeat it— Connell was in the passageway to the house in great distress and consternation. Hungerford moved to strike out 76300 and insert 16300. lost. Gordon moved 20000 which the chairman announced not in order, but the committee reversed this decision— Gordon then modified to 40000 Joseph J M’Dowell cited a speech of Silas Wright in the Senate which I answered— Rathbun moved to report the bill with recommendation to reject it—lost. I moved to rise, and report the Bill— Carried— Passed to a third reading by yeas and nays—90 to 67. and passed and reconsideration refused— It has yet to go through the ordeal of the Senate— Visit from Mr Perry of South Carolina, son of a man who migrated to that State, from Sherburne, Massachusetts— He is going to enquire for kindred of his own name— Evening visit from our neighbour Mr James Buchanan Secretary of State—

The Revd. E. Yulee of Woodward College, Cincinnati a Minister of the New Jerusalem Church, performed the service of public worship in the Hall of the house of Representatives this morning— I suppose him to be an Israelite, converted to Swedenborg Christianity— He read some passages from the Bible—made a short and frigid prayer—gave out by two lines at a time to be sung the hymns With one consent let all the Earth, To God their cheerful voices raise— Read the 53d chapter of Isaiah, and delivered a cold address of half an hour, upon the 4th. verse of that chapter.— “Surely, he hath borne our griefs and carried our sorrows; yet we did esteem him stricken, smitten of God, and afflicted.” Upon this text he engrafted the doctrine of correspondences so as to make it more unintelligible than it is by Swedenborg himself— There were I think not fifty persons in the hall, but among them was the Senator from Florida, the quondam David Levy—with his wife— He spoke to his namesake the preacher after the Service. I have received a pamphlet on this correspondence of natural things to spiritual by T. H. Perry professor of Mathematics in U.S. Navy— At 5 this afternoon I went to St. John’s Church, but found all the doors closed— There was no evening service there— I read the first of the Revd Daniel Baker’s revival Sermons—on the excellency of the Christian Religion; but the argument of the discourse is rather upon the evidence than the excellence of Christianity— Mr Baker complains of the unreasonable calls of unbelievers for evidence— It is strange that all professed arguments upon the Evidences, result in exciting and multiplying questions in my mind— We must recur to Faith. Mr Moseley the member from Buffalo made us an Evening visit— Spirits much discomposed

The time for morning bath in the Potowmack now suits exactly, but I am discouraged by a drooping state of health, and symptoms admonitory which I dare not disregard— I met at the Capitol Mr Healey the painter, and went with him to Plumbe’s gallery where they took two Daguerrotype full lengths likenesses of me, both very indifferent— He wanted it to introduce me as a spectator into the historical picture of Daniel Webster answering Robert Y. Hayne in the debate in the U.S. Senate on Foote’s Resolutions in 1831—which he is to paint for certain Boston Whigs to be suspended in Faneuil Hall— I told Mr Healey that I must decline being introduced into that picture, not having been a member of the Senate at that time, nor present at the scene— I was residing in this City in private life, from 3. March 1829. until December 1831. when I took my seat as a member of the House of Representatives Healey told me that he was engaged also to paint a historical picture of John C. Calhoun in some oratorical attitude, as a counterpart to this illustration of Daniel Webster, to be hung up somewhere at Charleston S.C— and that these two works would be the great labour of his life— He said he should leave this city next Thursday and after stopping at Philadelphia to paint a copy of Inman’s portrait of Chief Justice Marshall should proceed to Boston and embark in the Steamer of the 16th. of August to return to France and after thus accomplishing his Commission from king Louis Philippe he intends to come back here, to accomplish his two great historical pictures— On my return to the house, they immediately adjourned— The supplementary appropriation bill for Congressmen and Indians— The Senate’s amendment to the Army appropriation bill, and the navy pension bill, and the special order on the public printing were discussed. Garrett Davis. I came home quite unwell

IV.15— My indisposition continues and increases—till I am all but totally disabled for action or for thought— Dr Thomas himself much indisposed administers to me much advice and medicines in abundance, and I still attend at my seat in the house of Representatives.— This morning Thurman moved to discharge the Committee of the whole from the consideration of the Bill relating to the payment of claims against the Government. This was carried, and the Bill was taken up in the house, passed and sent to the Senate— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, Linn Boyd Chairman, upon a joint Resolution from the Senate regulating the printing for the two houses of Congress, a perpetual source of wrangling between the democratic and whig parties, each underbidding the other for economy, and each lavish without stint? to fatten their favourite printers with jobs— Garrett Davis finished his speech commenced yesterday. Thomas H— Bailey answered him with an hour of dull invective, and self laudation— Rathbun emitted a speech against speech making, and moved the Committee to rise for a Resolution to close the debate this day—which was done— He moved in the house to close the debate at 1. P.M. Dromgoole moved 5— Cobb 3. both rejected. Cobb moved to lay the resolution on the table—lost— Rathbun’s hour of 1— prevailed— Committee again Linn Boyd Chairman— Henley, Bayly, Garrett Davis Douglass, and MKay moved amendments, all rejected, and the Resolution as it came from the Senate was reported to the house, engrossed, passed, and reconsideration refused 100 to 55— Houston of Alabama asked to be excused from voting, but was refused— J. J. M’Dowell asked to be excused, gave silly reasons, and withdrew his request. Committee again Dunlap chairman Thurman, Holmes, Jenkins debated till the Committee rose and the house adjourned.

I had a disturbed and almost sleepless Night. My strength like the Proteus of Virgil in liquid lapse away. My appetite turns to loathing, and without pain I feel as if all my bones were extracted from my body— Yet I write and notwithstanding earnest remonstrances attend my daily duties in the house— Mr Yulee the preacher of last Sunday morning in the Representatives Hall was this day introduced to me— He is of the new Jerusalem church or in other words a Swedenborgian—to me the most senseless of infatuated mysticisms— I have received a pamphlet by Thomas H. Perry, a professor of Mathematics in U.S. Navy, on the Correspondence of natural things to spiritual—republished from the New Jerusalem Magazine— Upon Geology. At the house Yost from th Committee on engraving reported a Resolution for 5000 extra copies of the map accompanying document 211, relating to mineral Lands on lake Superior—adopted— Houston afterwards moved to reconsider but failed. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Dunlap chairman on Charles S. Benton 17 New-York’s report from a select Committee of a joint Resolution directing the manner of procuring the printing for the two houses of Congress— Committee soon rose, and a resolution passed to close the debate at 1 this day— Accordingly at 1. O’Clock the voting commenced and the Resolutions were adopted— Committee of conference on the conflicting votes on the second army appropriation bill. M’Kay, Black of S.C and Ashmun Committee of the whole on the State of the Union upon the bill from the judiciary Committee to increase the duties that is the Salary of the Attorney General from 4500 to 6000 dollars— Debate, but no conclusion. I failed to get the floor. Came home sick.

A disturbed and desolate Night— Prostrate—desponding—weary of existence—but never ceasing praise to God for the numberless blessings of his Providence throughout my life, and so many of which I still enjoy—never ceasing to pray for his sustaining hand through the dispensations yet in reserve, and especially for the controul of my own heart for Patience, and Resignation— I still attend the Meetings of the house and yesterday made several attempts to get the floor without success— This morning Douglass his motion to close debate on the Bill to increase the duties of the Attorney General in one hour—modified to One O’Clock was adopted Joseph R. Ingersoll offered a joint Resolution—argumentative and verbose, advising the President to propose to Mexico a Negotiation for Peace, and hinting at an arbitration, but the house would not receive it— The Bill to increase the duties, that is the powers and salary of the Attorney General was riddled in Union Committee debate, till one O’Clock then strip’d of its noxious parts, and loaded with others by successive amendments; a substitute offered by Tibbatts was at last reported to the house, and then at the motion of Roberts laid on the table Its only real object was to give an enormous increase of power and of profit to the Office of Attorney General— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Richard Broadhead 10 Pennsylvania Chairman, Bill for erection and repair of certain defensive fortifications— Tibbatts moved to authorize P.U.S to suspend all works of fortification during the Mexican War Long speech of Henry J. Seaman 2. New-York. Amendments were proposed by Giles of Maryland Elias B Holmes 28 New-York, Grinnell, Massachusetts W. W. Campbell 6 New-York, and Joseph R. Ingersoll to refer the Pea Patch question to Chief Justice Taney. Hungerford moved an amendment for Sackets harbour, Committee rose. Letter from P. M. Butler, about treating with Camanche Indians. Burt’s motion and adjourn.

I have an occasional or rather annual outscouring to go through in the month of July, in which I was born, and its operation has been this year has been more severe than usual; but I hope the crisis of it is now past, and I am this day convalescent for the present— There is another subject of reflection in my condition upon which it becomes me to commune only with myself.— I received this morning a Letter from James R. Snowden Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.— Treasury Office Harrisburg 26 July 1846. enclosing a draft on the Bank of Pennsylvania of 20 dollars in favour of Nathaniel Chick or order, which he had requested should be forwarded to me— But Chick did not appear this day— At the House Linn Boyd moved a joint Resolution that the hour for adjournment of the Session on the 10th. of August should be Noon— Adopted. Armistead Burt of S.C. moved a select Committee of 5. to enquire and report on the legality and propriety of the expenditures of Butler and Lewis, Commissioners to the Camanches and other tribes of Indians— The Resolution was adopted and afterwards reconsidered and laid on the table. It was a South Carolina dragooning and whipped M’Kay back into the traces— Joseph R. Ingersoll moved to suspend the rules for a joint resolution recommending to the President to negotiate for Peace with Mexico. Fudge. Suspension of rules, refused. Numerous Reports from Committees received— D— P— King moved a Resolution to allow each member 30 dollars for the long and 15 for the short Session instead of Stationery. Laid on the table. Warehousing Bill received from the Senate— Question of its commitment. Postponed to next Monday. Private Bills. 85 passed and sent to the Senate 93 objected to and passed over— Committee of the whole rose, and the house adjourned at 3. O’Clock.

Recovering from the total prostration of my faculties of body, and almost as total of the energies of mind I endeavour once more to resume some useful occupation—in vain. The house confined itself almost entirely to the consideration of private bills—taking up first the bills from the Senate reported yesterday from the committee of the whole— Among these was the bill for the relief of Amos Kendall, upon which there have been repeated decisions against him, and on which he was for years within prison bounds. The last decision was in his favour, and uncle Sam pays the piper— There was also a bill granting a small sum to Mrs Pike, widow of Zebulon Montgomery Pike, killed in an invasion of upper Canada in 1813 during the last War with Great Britain— But this was for services of exploration in 1805 and 1806 after the purchase of Louisiana. Daniel of N.C. Chairman of the Committee of Claims opposed it tooth and nail— So did Atkinson of Virginia, and Houston of Alabama, who moved to lay it on the table. But it was supported by Gordon and Culver, and passed 88 to 64— This day closed with a bill for the settlement of the accounts of John Garnett an Indian agent, which was read a third time, but on the question of its passage no quorum voted, and after an ineffectual motion for a call of the house they adjourned before one O’Clock— I went into the Senate chamber, and heard Daniel Webster speak about two hours against the bill to reduce the import duties and repeal the Tariff of 1842. The hall was crowded and he has the faculty of claiming the attention of his auditory—but his argument was dull, tedious and commonplace. I left him speaking after 3— Mr John Connell was here this Evening.

The Revd Flanders a Universalist from Saint Louis Missouri preached this morning in the Hall of the House of Representatives— His forms of worship are those of the Congregational church, but his mode of prayer seemed to me not quite sufficiently devotional. He gave out two hymns, from the collection used by the unitarian Society, in the city and they were sung by persons of the auditory present, which was not large— The text of Mr Flanders was Genesis 1.28. [“]And God blessed them, and God said unto them, be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth, and subdue it”— The preacher probably did not know, that this was precisely the passage cited by me on the 2d. of January last as the primitive foundation of our title to the Oregon Territory— The Doctrine deduced from it by Mr Flanders was that Man was by the Constitution of his Nature was created a laborious animal— That the condition of his existence in the Garden of Eden, before the fall was labour He gave notice that the Revd. Mr Yulee would preach at the Unitarian Church this afternoon at 4 O’Clock, and he himself this Evening at 8— There was no evening service at St. John’s. I wished to attend in the afternoon at 4 at the Unitarian Church, but was forbidden owing to the intense heat of the weather I did attend at 8 in the evening, and heard Mr Flanders, from John 8.32. [“]And ye shall know the truth and the truth shall make you free”— But what is truth? The Sermon was a very earnest discourse to prove the universal salvation of all mankind— As in Adam all died, so in Christ shall all be made alive— I hope so, and still find some consolation in attendance upon public worship— I am encouraged with continued symptoms of convalescence

V.— Fahrenheit 82—the temperature of the Night Life seems returning to me, and with it the longing for the Potowmac bath and swim— But I have not the command of my own limbs and cannot go— Nor can I yet keep along with the current of my correspondence, or of the public business with which I am concerned— I answered three Letters from a man named Sizer, enquiring concerning a petition presented originally by Osmyn Baker, and against which the Committee of claims reported last March— I have received also a Letter from J. Bigelow agent for the heirs of Francois Cazaux, in whose favour there is a bill before the house—and a report from the judiciary Committee— Also a printed Circular from Wiley and Putnam 26. July 1846. New York, enclosing another to the Secretary of State of the several States proposing to purchase public documents and books for the Managers of the British Museum— At the House the Speaker announced the Warehousing bill as the special order of the day but it was postponed till next Wednesday, and a Resolution was adopted to close the debate on the fortification bill at Noon this day— The Bill was immediately taken up in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Orville Hungerford Chairman and Ashmun made an hour speech against the President for the War with Mexico. M’Kay took no notice of it but talked about the fortifications— Burt wasted some ten minutes and 12. O’Clock came. Numerous additional amendments were proposed and rejected— That offered by Joseph R. Ingersoll authorising the President to settle for the Pea patch Island was adopted and the Bill passed— The Postage bill was next taken up and debated till for lack of a quorum the Committee rose and the house adjourned— I went into the Senate chamber and heard Mr Jarnagin.

IV:30— The remnant of my life is a long disease— A succession of complaints disable me for all active exertion of mind or of body and I no sooner seem to recover from one, than I am stricken down by another— I am especially deprived of that continuity of application to particular subjects indispensable for the transaction of business public or private. The course of Legislation carried on by the present administration of the Government is vicious and pernicious, but it is sustained by the will or the acquiescence of the People— The Nation is plunged into an unjust and wicked War—and not only submits to it, but wages it as if it were a War of self defence: I still receive numerous applications from individuals to assist them in the prosecution of their claims but am often unable to follow them up with that unintermitting attention without which it is impossible to carry them through— At the house, Strong and Culver moved Resolutions concerning the distribution of document books to the new members which failed for lack of two thirds majorities to suspend the rules— The Postage bill was taken up in Union Committee David S. Reid 3. North Carolina—with a long rigmarole episode, about the resignation of W. H. Haywood a Senator from that State. Briggs, Barringer, Dobbin Dockery discoursed about it and about it—all a-propos of the Post office bill, till soon after 2. the Committee rose, and the house adjourned— I went into the Senate chamber where John M. Niles Senator from Connecticut was blowing the last blast against the Tariff bill—in vain— The engrossment of the bill had been carried by the casting vote of the Vice-President George M. Dallas, and the bill passed 28 to 27.— Mr John Connell here this Eve.

I received 26. Letters, printed, all of one tenor but signed by different individuals, from Nantucket, invoking my influence in support of the bill to indemnify the sufferers by French spoliations before 1800. The appeal to my feelings is most impressive—but the day of my strength is past, and an atmosphere at 90 degrees of Fahrenheit annihilating. A Scotchman by the name of Stewart was here— A benevolent undertaker to promote the migration of his poor Countrymen to the United States, and soliciting money for himself which I declined to give— At the House the new tariff bill was received from the Senate with an amendment striking out the 9th. Section— The special order of the day, the Warehouse bill was postponed till to-morrow. Call of the house 211 answered 10 absent 4 vacancies— The question to suspend the special order and take up the Message from the Senate was carried 108 to 100. Winthrop claimed that it could be carried only by a two thirds vote— The Speaker said it was too late to raise the objection— Winthrop appealed and the appeal was laid on the table. 102 to 98. Stewart moved to lay the bill with the Senate’s amendment on the table, lost 96 to 113.— A second motion to lay the bill on the table was rejected 99 to 113—and the concurrence with the amendment of the Senate was carried 115 to 92— And thus perishes the Tariff of 1842. Carried by a majority of one John White then Speaker of the House, and now repeated by the casting vote of George M Dallas Vice President of the United States and President of the Senate— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, upon the Post Office Bill, debated till of the 210 who had voted on the Tariff bill there was not a quorum of 113 left, and after some convulsive throes, the Committee rose, and the house adjourned.

My colleague Benjamin Thompson, member from the 4th. Congressional District of Massachusetts, put into my hands a Letter to him from Elijah Clark of Brighton 27. July—stating that he had forwarded to me a pension claim of Lydia Weston to which no answer has been received— It is one of many cases received from Mr Clark, and the circumstances of which have escaped from my memory— I received also a Letter from John Barrett, Waggoners Ripple Post Office Adams County Ohio soliciting for a pension claim of an old widow named Mary Taylor, daughter of William Flood or Floid—Revolutionary Soldier, and Mr Barrett encloses a Letter of 3 June 1846 to him from the Commissioner of Pensions importing that Mrs Mary Taylor has no claim at all— At the house the special order of the day was again postponed and after Thomasson had introduced a bill to establish a post road from this city to the Columbia river in the Oregon territory Hopkins’s new Post-Office bill was resumed in Committee of the whole, on the state of the Union David S. Reid 3. North Carolina Chairman— A snarl of debate followed upon swarming amendments till Hopkins took a vote upon his substitute for the whole bill which was rejected 81 to 96. Then Owen moved to reconsider that rejection— The Committee had risen for lack of a quorum and been discharged from consideration of the bill Rathbun moved to lay Owen’s motion of reconsideration on the table This was carried 94 to 84—and Dromgoole as Speaker, decided that it carried the bill with it— Bill about Java Coffee and duties on Spanish vessels—passed with an amendment from the Senate— French spoliation bill outbreak of Allen Y. ThurmanOhio against it He had not finished when the Committee rose and the house adjourned

I received a Letter from Rufus W. Griswold dated yesterday at Philadelphia enclosing a printed notice of 3. octavo pages headed John Quincy Adams—and asking copies of my Oration at Cincinnati, and my speech against the admission of Texas— At the house instead of resuming the consideration of the French spoliation bill, they went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, upon the Warehousing system bill, which was the special order of the day. M’Kay moved a Call of the house and 165 answered to their names— Hilliard of Alabama opened the debate, by moving to strike out the first section, except the enacting clause, and he spoke an hour against the bill, and about the Tariff of 1842 and its repeal just consummated, for which he voted though he had many objections to the new bill— Truman Smith of Connecticut followed with a heavy and bitter invective against the repeal of the Tariff of 1842.— Thomas H. Bayly and W. W. Payne of Alabama consumed two successive hours in railing not in good fat terms, but in hectoring commonplace against the tariff of 1842. Andrew Stewart of Pennsylvania replied to them both in a tone somewhat like their own though much more spirited— John G. Chapman 3. Maryland took the floor— The Committee rose and the house adjourned— William H. Haywood junr. published this day in the National Intelligencer a notice to the People of North-Carolina, that he intends to publish in a few days an address to them in justification of his recent resignation of his Seat as a member of the Senate of the United States.
